Award.AwardTitle: Coupled Aerosol and Climate Models: An Intercomparison of the GFDL Model and the NCAR Model
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to examine the relationships between aerosol changes, cloud changes and climate change using the Integrated Massively Parallel Atmospheric Chemical Transport (IMPACT) aerosol model coupled to two different climate models and to evaluate the adequacy of the aerosol treatment and cloud treatments within the two versions of the coupled IMPACT/climate models. Specifically, the investigators will (i) couple the aerosol model to the Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Laboratory (GFDL) atmospheric general circulation model (AGCM) and the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR) Community Atmosphere Model (CAM) models that will be used in the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change 5th assessment report (AR5) simulations, (ii) compare how different parameterizations in the models as well as basic model dynamics help determine the cloud fields, aerosol fields, and direct and indirect forcing by aerosols, and (iii) study the relative changes to clouds from changes in climate and from aerosols.

This project will help to determine which climate model transport, chemical transformation, and removal for aerosols is best able to reproduce satellite data for aerosol optical depth, ratio of extinction as a function of wavelength, backscattering profiles, and the effective radius of aerosols. It may also help to reduce the range of sensitivity of climate models to increases in greenhouse gases.

Broader impacts of this project concern both its policy implications and the training of scientific personnel. The issues being addressed are of prime importance in the determination of climate change and its prediction. The use of models that are being submitted to the next IPCC AR5 report will help the understanding and comparison two primary U.S. models used in that policy-relevant report. In addition, a graduate student as well as a post-doctoral will be trained and results from this project are routinely used to update the Precipitation and Clouds course taught by one of the investigators.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our goals in this project were to understand the causes of differences between predicted aerosols in the NCAR CAM5 model and the GFDL AM3 model as well as to extend this understanding to differences in predicted climate forcing. We used off-line meteorological fields from each model together with the IMPACT aerosol model to examine differences. We also examined differences for predicting the effects of aircraft emissions in the standard CAM5 model and the CAM5 model when run in a manner similar to that of the IMPACT aerosol model coupled to CAM3. Finally, the IMPACT aerosol treatment was coupled on-line with the CAM5 meteorology.

Over all, the IMPACT-AM3 model predicts larger burdens and longer aerosol lifetimes than the IMPACT-CAM5 model. However, the IMPACT-CAM5 simulations transport more black carbon to the polar regions and more dust from Asia towards North America. The largest differences in CAM5 and AM3 are caused by differences in: 1) the vertical cloud mass flux and large-scale precipitation fields which determine the wet deposition of aerosols; 2) the in-cloud liquid water content and the cloud coverage which determine the wet aqueous phase production of sulfate. Even though IMPACT-CAM5 has smaller aerosol burdens, its AOD is larger due to the much higher relative humidity in CAM5.  The corresponding global annual average anthropogenic and all-sky aerosol direct forcing at the top of the atmosphere ranges from -0.25 W m-2 to -0.30 W m-2 for IMPACT-AM3 and from -0.48 W m-2 to -0.64 W m-2 for IMPACT-CAM5.

We further developed the CAM5 model to interactively couple CAM5 and IMPACT. We studied the effects of aircraft soot on cirrus clouds using the standard assumptions in the CAM5 aerosol/ice formation model and using assumptions that are similar to those in the IMPACT model. Thus, we varied the background number concentration of sulfate aerosols that were allowed to act as homogeneous ice nucleation sites as well as the dust concentrations that act as heterogeneous ice nuclei to examine the sensitivity of the forcing by aircraft soot to the background atmosphere. With high sulfate and low dust number concentrations, the predicted forcing by aircraft soot is -0.35 W m-2 whereas with low sulfate and low dust (the normal CAM5 set-up) the forcing is 0.09 Wm-2.

We ran several versions of the CAM3+ model coupled to the IMPACT aerosol model and the CoCiP contrail formation model. These simulations were extended to 30 years in an effort to find a signal of the effects of hydrological changes induced by the emissions of water vapor and contrail formation by aircraft. The contrail properties from CoCiP/CAM/IMPACT were in reasonable agreement with observations. Aged contrails may contail 106 times the water emitted by aircraft. Ice in contrails grows and sediments down, evaporating and depositing the water on average 700 m below the aircraft flight corridor. The contrail-thinning caused by this reduces the contrail radiative forcing by about 15%. In this simulation, approximately 12% of the soot particles freeze within contrails, so forcing results should be smaller than previous simulations that had assumed 20%.
